name: to_js_object
description: Converts this value to a JSON serializable object.

name: Value
arguments:
- field_names: Set of column names (Vector Text).
- getter: Get the value for a field name.

name: Value
arguments:
- original_value: The original value from before conversion.
- length: The number of rows in the table.
- getter: Get the value for a specified row.
- columns: The names for the columns when object is expanded.
  These will be added to the name of the input column.
- is_sequence: Whether the object is a sequence-like aggregate. This will
  affect the `expand_sequences_only` option of `expand_to_rows` method.

name: to_vector
description: Return the iterator values as a `Vector`.

name: align_sequence_only
description:
Aligns this conversion depending on if we want to only expand sequences
or all kinds of objects.

If `sequence_only` is `False` or the conversion reports `is_sequence=True`, no changes are made.
However, `sequence_only` is `True` and the conversion reports `is_sequence=False`,
the conversion is replaced with a single row - same as the `Any` fallback.

name: Pair
arguments:
- key: The key of the pair.
- value: The value of the pair.

name: get
description: Return the key of the pair.

name: Delimited
description:
Read delimited files such as CSVs into a Table.

When reading this format, the following problems may occur:
- If a row does not match the first row's column count, the function
  raises an `Invalid_Row`.
- If an empty file is passed, an `Empty_File_Error` is thrown.
- If a quote is opened and never closed, a `File_Error.Corrupted_Format`
  error is raised.
arguments:
- delimiter: The delimiter character to split the file into columns. An
  `Illegal_Argument` error is returned if this is an empty string.
- encoding: The encoding to use when reading the file.
- skip_rows: The number of rows to skip from the top of the file.
- row_limit: The maximum number of rows to read from the file. This count
  does not include the header row (if applicable).
- quote_style: Specifies the style of quotes used for reading and
  writing.
- headers: Specifies if the first row contains the  column names. If set
  to `Detect_Headers`, the process tries to infer if headers are
  present. If the column names are not unique, numeric suffixes will be
  appended to disambiguate them.
- value_formatter: Formatter to parse text values into numbers, dates,
  times, etc. If `Nothing` values are left as Text.
- on_invalid_rows: Specifies how to handle rows that have less or more
  columns than the first row.
- line_endings: Sets the line ending style to use. Defaults to `Infer` -
  when reading a file or appending to an existing file, the line endings
  are detected from file contents; when writing a new file in `Infer`
  mode the `Unix` line endings are used.
- comment_character: Sets the character which indicates the start of a
  comment within a delimited file. Any line that begins with the comment
  character is skipped. The comment character is treated as any other
  character if it anywhere else than at the beginning of the line. This
  option is only applicable for read mode and does not affect writing. It
  defaults to `Nothing` which means that comments are disabled.

name: resolve
description: Resolve an unresolved constructor to the actual type.

name: for_read
description: If the File_Format supports reading from the file, return a configured instance.

name: for_file_write
description: If this File_Format should be used for writing to that file, return a configured instance.

name: read
description: Implements the `File.read` for this `File_Format`

name: read_stream
description: Implements decoding the format from a stream.

name: write_table
description: Implements the `Table.write` for this `File_Format`.

name: clone
description: Clone the instance with some properties overridden.

name: with_quotes
description: Create a clone of this with specified quoting settings.

name: without_quotes
description: Create a clone of this with specified quoting settings.

name: with_headers
description: Create a clone of this with first row treated as header.

name: without_headers
description:
Create a clone of this where the first row is treated as data, not a
header.

name: with_parsing
description:
Create a clone of this with value parsing.

A custom `Data_Formatter` can be provided to customize parser options.

name: without_parsing
description: Create a clone of this without value parsing.

name: with_line_endings
description: Creates a clone of this with a changed line ending style.

name: with_comments
description: Creates a clone of this with comment parsing enabled.

name: without_comments
description: Creates a clone of this with comment parsing disabled.

name: from
description: Constructs a `Delimited` instance from JSON.

name: Drop_Invalid_Rows
description: Rows that contain too few or too many columns are dropped.

name: Keep_Invalid_Rows
description:
Rows that contain too few or too many columns are kept

- If a row has too few columns, the missing columns are filled with `Nothing`.
- If it has too many, the extra columns are dropped.

name: Add_Extra_Columns
description:
Rows that contain more columns than expected are kept, and the extra columns are added.

- If a row has too few columns, the missing columns are filled with `Nothing`.
- If it has too many, the extra columns are kept. The previous rows that
  had less columns are filled with `Nothing`.

name: from
description: A conversion for backward compatibility.

name: No_Quotes
description:
Do not quote any values or parse quotes when reading a `Delimited` file.

In write mode, values are not quoted even if this would result in an
invalid file.

name: With_Quotes
description: Specifies the style of quotes when reading or writing a `Delimited` file.
arguments:
- quote: The quote character denotes the start and end of a quoted value.
  Quoted items are not split on the delimiter and can also contain
  newlines. Empty input strings must be quoted (e.g. "") as otherwise an
  empty value is treated as `Nothing`.
- quote_escape: The character to escape the quote character in a quoted
  value. For example, if both `quote` and `quote_escape` are set to `"`,
  then escaping quotes is done by double quotes: `"ab""cd"` will yield
  the text `ab"cd`. Another popular choice for `quote_escape` is the `\`
  character. Then `"ab\"cd"` will yield the same text.
remarks:
! Quote Character

  The quote and escape characters must consist of exactly one code-point
  (i.e. it can be only one character and complex characters like emojis
  may not be used).

name: Always_Quote
description: Always quote text values when reading or writing a `Delimited` file.
arguments:
- quote: The quote character denotes the start and end of a quoted value.
  Quoted items are not split on the delimiter and can also contain
  newlines. Empty input strings must be quoted (e.g. "") as otherwise an
  empty value is treated as `Nothing`.
- quote_escape: The character to escape the quote character in a quoted
  value. For example, if both `quote` and `quote_escape` are set to `"`,
  then escaping quotes is done by double quotes: `"ab""cd"` will yield
  the text `ab"cd`. Another popular choice for `quote_escape` is the `\`
  character. Then `"ab\"cd"` will yield the same text.
remarks:
! Quote Character

  The quote and escape characters must consist of exactly one code-point
  (i.e. it can be only one character and complex characters like emojis
  may not be used).

name: Workbook
description: Reads an Excel file as a connection to an `Excel_Workbook`.
arguments:
- xls_format:
  If set to `True`, the file is read as an Excel 95-2003 format.
  If set to `False`, the file is read as an Excel 2007+ format.
  `Infer` will attempt to deduce this from the extension of the filename.
- default_sheet: The default sheet to use when writing a table to a file
  with these format settings.

name: Sheet
description: Reads a sheet from an Excel file as a `Table`.
arguments:
- sheet: The sheet number or name.
- headers: Specifies if the first row contains the  column names. If set
  to `Detect_Headers`, the process tries to infer if headers are
  present. If the column names are not unique, numeric suffixes will be
  appended to disambiguate them.
- skip_rows: The number of rows to skip before reading the data.
- row_limit: The maximum number of rows to read.
- xls_format:
  If set to `True`, the file is read as an Excel 95-2003 format.
  If set to `False`, the file is read as an Excel 2007+ format.
  `Infer` will attempt to deduce this from the extension of the filename.

name: Range
description: Reads a range from an Excel file as a `Table`.
arguments:
- address: A name of a range or an Excel-style address (e.g. Sheet1!A1:B2).
- headers: Specifies if the first row contains the  column names. If set
  to `Detect_Headers`, the process tries to infer if headers are
  present. If the column names are not unique, numeric suffixes will be
  appended to disambiguate them.
- skip_rows: The number of rows to skip before reading the data.
- row_limit: The maximum number of rows to read.
- xls_format:
  If set to `True`, the file is read as an Excel 95-2003 format.
  If set to `False`, the file is read as an Excel 2007+ format.
  `Infer` will attempt to deduce this from the extension of the filename.

name: resolve
description: Resolve an unresolved constructor to the actual type.

name: for_read
description: If the File_Format supports reading from the file, return a configured instance.

name: for_file_write
description: If this File_Format should be used for writing to that file, return a configured instance.

name: read
description: Implements the `File.read` for this `File_Format`

name: read_stream
description: Implements decoding the format from a stream.

name: write_table
description:
Implements the `Table.write` for this `File_Format`.

Depending on the `section` will control where to write.
- If `Excel_Section.Workbook` (the default), the `table` will be written
  to a new sheet in the workbook named `Sheet<n>` where n is the first
  integer >1 that is not already used as a sheet name. If too many sheets
  are present an `Illegal_Argument` error will be thrown.
- If `Excel_Section.Worksheet`, the `table` will be written to the
  specified sheet (either adding or replacing).
- If `Excel_Section.Cell_Range`, the `table` will be written to the
  specified range.
arguments:
- file: The file to write to.
- table: The table to write.
- on_existing_file: What to do if the file already exists.
- match_columns: How to match columns between the table and the file.
- on_problems: What to do if there are problems reading the file.

name: should_treat_as_xls_format
description: Resolve the xls_format setting to a boolean.

name: xls_format_from_metadata
description:
This function returns:
- `True` if the file is an XLS format,
- `False` if the file is an XLSX format,
- `Nothing` if the file is not an Excel format.

name: as_section
description: Converts this format to a corresponding `Excel_Section`.

name: from
description:
Constructs an `Excel_Format` instance from JSON.
Only a subset of options is currently supported.

name: Value
description: Specifies a range within an Excel Workbook.

name: is_valid_column
description:
Validates if a column index (1-based) is within the valid range for
Excel.
arguments: - column: 1-based index to check.

name: is_valid_row
description: Validates if a row index (1-based) is within the valid range for Excel.
arguments: - row: 1-based index to check.

name: column_index
description:
Given a column name, parses to the index (1-based) or return index
unchanged.

name: from_address
description: Creates a Range from an address.

name: for_cell
description: Create a Range for a single cell.

name: for_range
description: Create an Excel_Range for a range of cells.

name: for_columns
description: Create an Excel_Range for a set of columns.

name: for_rows
description: Create an Excel_Range for a set of rows.

name: column_name_for_index
description: Convert an index (1-based) to a column name

name: column_index_for_name
description: Convert a column name to an index (1-based)

name: sheet_name
description: Gets the name of the sheet.

name: top_row
description:
Gets the index (1-based) of the top row of the range.
Returns `Nothing` if referring to a complete column.

name: bottom_row
description:
Gets the index (1-based) of the bottom row of the range.
Returns `Nothing` if referring to a complete column.

name: left_column
description:
Gets the index (1-based) of the left column of the range.
Returns `Nothing` if referring to a complete row.

name: right_column
description:
Gets the index (1-based) of the right column of the range.
Returns `Nothing` if referring to a complete row.

name: is_single_cell
description: Is the Excel_Range referring to a single cell

name: address
description: Gets the address to this in A1 format.

name: to_text
description: Displays the Excel_Range.

name: validate
description: Wrapper for validation of a value prior to execution.

name: Value
description: Creates an Excel_Workbook connection.

name: new
description: Load a File as a connection to an Excel workbook.
arguments:
- file: The file to load.
- xls_format: Whether to use the old XLS format (default is XLSX).

name: from_stream
description: Load an Input_Stream as a connection to an Excel workbook.
arguments:
- stream: The stream to load.
- xls_format: Whether to use the old XLS format (default is XLSX).
- file: Optional file reference.

name: xls_format
description: Is the Workbook in the old XLS format?

name: databases
description: Returns the list of databases (or catalogs) for the connection.

name: database
description: Returns the name of the current file.

name: set_database
description: Returns a new Workbook with the specified file.
arguments: - database: The target file to open as an Excel_Workbook.

name: schemas
description: Returns the list of schemas for the connection within the current database (or catalog).

name: schema
description: Returns the name of the current schema.

name: set_schema
description: Returns a new Workbook with the specified schema set as default.
arguments: - schema: The name of the schema to connect to.

name: sheet_count
description: Gets the number of sheets.

name: sheet_names
description: Gets the names of all the sheets.

name: named_ranges_count
description: Gets the number of named ranges.

name: named_ranges
description: Gets the names of all the named ranges.

name: table_types
description: Gets a list of the table types.

name: tables
description: Returns a materialised Table of all the matching views and tables.
arguments:
- name_like: The table name pattern to search for. Support SQL wildcards (`%`, `_`).
- database: The database name to search in (default is current database).
- schema: The schema name to search in (defaults to current schema).
- types: The table types to search for. The list of values can be obtained using the `table_types` method.
- all_fields: Return all the fields in the metadata table.

name: query
description: Read a range into a Table.
arguments:
- query: sheet name, range name or address to read from the workbook.
- alias: optionally specify a friendly alias for the query (unused).
- headers: whether to use the first row as headers (default is
  `Detect_Headers`).

name: read
description: Read a range into a Table.
arguments:
- query: sheet name, range name or address to read from the workbook.
- headers: whether to use the first row as headers (default is
  `Detect_Headers`).
- limit: the maximum number of rows to read.
  If set to `Nothing`, all rows will be returned.

name: read_section
description: Read an Excel_Section from the Workbook
arguments: - section: the section to read.

name: sheet
description: Reads a worksheet from the workbook.
arguments:
- name: the name of the worksheet to read.
- headers: whether to use the first row as headers (default is
  `Detect_Headers`).

name: close
description:
Closes the workbook, releasing any resources it holds.

This method may be used to release the underlying workbook file,
e.g. to be able to delete it.

After this method is called, this instance is not usable any more - any
operation on it will throw an `Illegal_State` error.

name: to_text
description: Returns a simple text description of the workbook.

name: to_display_text
description: Returns a short human-readable text representation of the workbook.

name: to_js_object
description: Provides a JS object representation for use in visualizations.

name: read_many
description: Reads one or more sheets into a Table.
arguments:
- sheet_names: the names of sheets, ranges or addresses to read.
  Defaults to all sheets. An invalid `sheet_name` will be reported as a
  problem.
- headers: whether to use the first row as headers (default is
  `Detect_Headers`) for each sheet.
- return: how to return the tables. Defaults to `As_Merged_Table` meaning
  the tables are merged into a single table.
- on_problems: how to handle problems during reading. Defaults to
  `Report_Warning`.

name: Table_Of_Tables
description:
DEPRECATED
Each sheet is returned as a row.

This option is deprecated, because it has been renamed. Please use the
equivalent `With_New_Column` instead.

name: Merged_Table
description:
DEPRECATED
All sheets are merged into a single table. A union operation is performed.

This option is deprecated, because it has been renamed. Please use the
equivalent `As_Merged_Table` instead.

name: _resolve_return_as_compatibility
description:
A helper method that ensures that we can take the new `Return_As_Table` type
as well as the deprecated `Return_As` type, together with autoscoping.
With autoscoping, the `As_Merged_Table` constructor is ambiguous, so plain
autoscoping would not work and we do some workarounds to make it work.
In case of the ambiguity, the new-style `Return_As_Table.As_Merged_Table`
variant is preferred.

name: _query_widget
description: Creates a query widget for the `read` method.

name: from
description: Loads all sheets in the Excel workbook and merges them into a single table.

name: to_column
description: Creates a column from a `Vector` of values.
arguments: - name: Name of the new column.

name: to_column
description: Creates a column from a `Range` of values.
arguments: - name: Name of the new column.

name: to_column
description: Creates a column from a `Date_Range` of values.
arguments: - name: Name of the new column.

name: from_excel
description: Converts an Excel date to a `Date`.

name: from_excel
description: Converts an Excel date time to a `Date_Time`.

name: to_table
description: Converts this `Vector` into a `Table`.
arguments:
- fields: a Vector of Text representing the names of fields to look up.
  If `Nothing` then all fields found are added.

name: to_table
description: Converts this `Range` into a `Table`.
arguments: - name: The name of the column to use for the range.

name: to_table
description: Converts this `Date_Range` into a `Table`.
arguments: - name: The name of the column to use for the range.

name: to_table
description: Converts this `JS_Object` into a `Table`.
arguments:
- fields: a Vector of Text representing the names of fields to look up.
  If `Nothing` then all fields found are added.

name: to_table
description: Converts this `XML_Document` into a `Table`.

name: to_table
description: Converts this `XML_Document` into a `Table`.

name: from_objects
description:
Converts an object or a Vector of object into a Table, by looking up the
requested fields from each item.
arguments:
- value: The object or Vector of objects to convert to a table.
  If a Vector or Array, then each item is added as a row.
  Otherwise, treated as a single row.
- fields: a Vector of Text representing the names of fields to look up.
  If `Nothing` then all fields found are added.
examples:
> Example
  Converts a set of objects into a table using the provided headers.

      from Standard.Table import Table
      import Standard.Examples

      example_to_table =
          json = Examples.simple_table_json
          headers = Examples.simple_table_json_headers
          Table.from_objects json headers

name: parse_to_table
description:
Converts a Text into a Table using a regular expression pattern.

Each match becomes a row in the table.

If there are no marked groups, there will be a single column with the
whole content of the match. Otherwise, each group becomes a column
(with the column name taken from the group name if the group is named in the
regex).

For details on Enso's Regex syntax, see the [Help Documentation](https://help.enso.org/docs/using-enso/regular-expressions).
arguments:
- pattern: The regular expression as either `Text` or `Regex` to search within the text.
- case_sensitivity: Specifies if the text values should be compared case
  sensitively.
- parse_values: Parse any values using the default value parser.
remarks:
? Column Names

If there are no marked groups, the new column will be named `Column`.
If the marked groups are named, the names will be used otherwise the column
will be named `Column <N>` where `N` is the number of the marked group.
(Group 0 is not included.)

name: write_table
description: Implements the `Table.write` for this `JSON_File`.
arguments:

- table: The table to write.
- on_existing_file: What to do if the file already exists.
- match_columns: How to match columns between the table and the file.
  Not used for JSON.
- on_problems: What to do if there are problems reading the file.

name: append_to_json_table
description: Handles appending to a file containing a JSON table by removing the closing bracket and appending to it.
